Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Coordinated Data-Driven Modeling and Optimization for Wireless Sensor Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The need for comprehensive monitoring and analysis of complex environments has brought wireless sensor networks (WSNs) to the forefront of research. To be effective in practice, WSNs need to capture system state, monitor complex properties, and model physical phenomena accurately and robustly, without any biases. Currently, most efforts in this area employ parametric models and other a priori assumptions that postulate known phenomena and system properties. The characteristics of emerging complex applications, however, are often unknown and hard to predict. Thus, optimizations using models based on a priori assumptions often have limited effectiveness.

This research plan develops novel data-driven modeling methods, scalable modular structures, and application optimization algorithms that comprehensively abstract, capture and operate on traces of deployed WSNs. While the research thrusts are intended to provide applicable models, development tools, and system software for WSNs, they simultaneously advance the theory and practice of statistical modeling and optimization algorithms. The models and algorithms are coordinated: the models are built so that they facilitate consequent optimizations, while the optimization algorithms are created in such a way that they take into account the structure and uncertainties of the models. The results are intrinsically interdisciplinary and have impact on a broad range of other fields. This project integrates research and educational activities by engaging students in the research and by incorporating the research into both undergraduate and graduate levels. The research results and educational material are promptly disseminated via academic publications, the Connexions platform, and other WWW sources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal focused on creation of novel data-driven modeling methods, scalable modular structures, and application optimization algorithms that aim to comprehensively abstract, capture and operate on traces of deployed embedded devices and networks. Models and algorithms were coordinated:  models were built so that they facilitate application optimizations, while optimization algorithms were created in such a way that they take into account the structure and uncertainties of the models.

On the modeling front, we devised inter-device models that characterize  relationships among readings of different embedded platforms. The novelty lies in combining data-driven (nonparametric) and adaptive structure with shape constraints suggested by physical laws and operational parameters. Models were developed by mapping the statistical model building problem into the combinatorial domain. The models have polynomial complexity and are provably optimal with respect to the user's given error norm.

The coordinated optimization was pursued for ensuring integrity of chip's test data compared with expected outcomes. Our project built new data-driven models for reference chips and then created new and provably optimal Trojan detection method.  Several malware sizes, statistical distributions, and calibration methods were studied.

The methodology was also used to identify unique chip parameters, and also to develop new circuit constructs that can extract a profile of those characteristics. We addressed the problem of software integrity using data-driven and unique models extracted from each of the underlying embedded devices. Several security and data integrity protocols could be built upon these fundamental models.


A number of students in the PI's lab were supported on this project, about half of whom have been women. The PI funded WomenExCEL which has significantly contributed to diversity at Rice. New undergrad/graduate teaching courses and material have been developed. The project outcomes published in competitive conferences/journals. This CAREER project significantly helped the PI to launch her career as a junior faculty and has lasted throughout her assistant professor years. The PI and her groups have received several honors and awards for their research which was partly funded by this CAREER proposal.
